node.text:
"Donald Trump upended the American presidency after stepping away from the company that made him rich and famous. Four years later, returning to his empire after losing the White House, what he finds may upend him," write Sophie Alexander and Max Abelson.

"Three quarters of Trump's net worth is tied up in urban real estate. And urban real estate has been hammered by Covid-19," Tim O'Brien tells @quicktake's Tim Stenovec.

The former president's net worth is down to $2.3 billion from $3 billion in 2016. The pandemic he promised would disappear is walloping his company, and the riot that got him impeached for a second time is wounding his brand.

Check out "Trump’s Ailing Empire" on bloomberg.com/graphics to see just how deep in peril he really is.

node.title: How Will the GameStop Game Stop?

node.text:
👻 Snap Inc. is rolling out a new tool for its Snapchat app to feature popular videos, called Spotlight, and said it will pay out $1 million a day to creators of the top-performing posts. How good of a deal is that?

🤳🏻 "The more remarkable thing about Snap is that it wasn't offering these sort of incentives to people to create good content previously."

Alex Webb joined @quicktake's Tim Steno to explain why Snap decided to compensate viral creators.

#snapchat #influencer #app #creators #snap

node.title: Snapchat to Pay $1 Million a Day to Creators

node.text:
It’s been 20 months since a pair of fatal crashes forced regulators around the globe to ground the once top-selling jet. The FAA finally approved the Max to resume commercial flights today, which will allow Boeing to make money off the roughly 450 Max jets it has built but not yet delivered.

After the longest grounding of an aircraft in modern U.S. history, it’s reasonable to ask whether the plane is safe. Bloomberg Opinion columnists Chris Bryant and Brooke Sutherland teamed up to discuss the future of the Max, and whether or not they'd be willing to board one.

#Boeing #Boeing737 #737max #airplane #aircraft #airline #southwest #americanair #flight #pandemic #livestream #video #igtv #travel

node.title: Boeing’s 737 Max Is Back. Are You Willing to Board?

node.text:
Frank Barry didn’t ask a soul about Donald Trump or Joe Biden on his @looking4lincoln trip. For the two months he spent crossing the country along the Lincoln Highway by Winnebago, talking with Americans and hoping to reach San Francisco by Election Day, he never brought up the campaign. Sometimes he knew how people felt — occasionally they would say, though usually not. But it didn’t matter. He wasn’t running a focus group. He was trying to catch glimpses of a more enduring spirit, the kind that has transcended parties and generations, the kind that lives, as Lincoln said, in the better angels of our nature. And maybe those glimpses could help us see more of ourselves in each other, and in the land we share.

#lincolnhighway #travel #rv #roadtrip #winnebago #highway #ontheroad #interview #video

node.title: The End of the Lincoln Highway

node.title: The Supreme Court Debate Runs Along the Lincoln Highway

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on July 22, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Jamie Dimon didn't neeo $50 million, it'sstill still nice to feel loved BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Jamie Dimon’s five-year retirement joke just got serious.

The billionaire CEO of JPMorgan was granted a special gift to persuade him to stay on board: 1.5 million stock appreciation rights, which will let him capture a profit if the stock price rises in the coming years.

Matt Levine's model for executive compensation at the very high end — where Dimon and, like, Elon Musk reside — is that these are people who have moved beyond being motivated by money.

"My model is that the board got together and said 'hey Jamie has been doing a great job lately but he looks a little tired, we should do something to cheer him up and let him know that we’re thinking of him,' and one director suggested leaving a Post-It note on his monitor saying 'just wanted to say that we appreciate you,' and another director was like 'hey that's a great idea but let's also put $50 million under the note' and everyone else was like “oh well of course yes $50 million.” And he walked in to see the filing and was like “oh that was nice of them” and smiled for a minute and got back to work and never thought of the $50 million again, it's just $50 million, who cares," Levine writes.

It’s still nice to feel loved, and the love language of a public-company board is pretty much always going to be options grants. Tap the link to read Money Stuff in full.

#JPMorgan #JamieDimon #JPM #bonus

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on July 22, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Haiti's living standards haven't improved since the 1950s Haiti Dominican Republic Jamaica Per-capita GDP Costa Rica Cuba $20K 15 10 1960 1950 Û:'D Our World Data 1980 o 2000 2018 BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
🇭🇹Right now, Haiti is the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere. Even worse, by some measures Haiti’s living standards haven’t grown at all since 1950.

The country’s chronic dysfunction is both a result and a cause of its chronic poverty. It needs to focus on economic growth — and to do that, Haiti should copy its more successful neighbors like Jamaica and the Dominican Republic.

Noah Smith explains: “In 1950, Haiti was on a par with Jamaica and the Dominican Republic. As of 2018, it was less than one-third as rich as the former, and less than one-sixth as rich as the latter. This is one of the most spectacularly dismal economic failures in the modern world, and turning the situation around should be a galvanizing mission for Haitians, as well as for the U.S. and other neighbors in the region.”

The question , “Why is Haiti so poor?” is an interesting and complex one, rooted in history and politics. But instead of focusing on the past, Haitians should ask, “What will make Haiti less poor?” The likely answers are tourism and better agriculture. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion in Singapore. May be an image of text that says 'One karaoke lounge. That's allittook to shut down Singapore's nightlife. BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
🇸🇬It was just a matter of time before Singapore’s commitment to live with Covid-19 would be tested. The only surprise is how quickly that moment came and how avoidable it was.

On Friday, Singapore announced it would tighten certain social-distancing measures and ramp up contact tracing and testing to contain a cluster that started at a karaoke lounge.

Typically out of sight behind heavily tinted glass or soundproof doors, KTV hostesses greeted patrons mask-free. The women, many of them unvaccinated, split their time between multiple patrons and sometimes multiple locations. In short, a potential super-spreader event night after night after night.

In response, the government has suspended hundreds of nightlife venues for two weeks, and police have arrested 29 women. Ten of them, aged 21 to 34, were labeled “undesirable immigrants” by officials. They will be deported.

"This dramatic outcome was not inevitable. Nightclubs that transitioned to restaurants should have been flooded with oversight from the start," writes Rachel Rosenthal.

Singapore has been tightening rules for foreign workers and carefully monitoring its borders. How did it manage to lose track of its short-term visitors? Tap the link in our bio to find out.

#singapore #covid #ktv #ktvcluster

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Bloomberg Opinion on July 21, 2021 tagging @winnebagorvs, and @barlettapontoonboats. May be an image of text that says 'The booming RV business is expanding into pontoon boats Winnebago's revenue $4B 2 FY 2014 FY 2015 FY 2016 FY 2017 FY FY2018 FY 2019 FY 2020 FY 2021 FY 2022 Est Est Source: Souce:Bloomberg BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Winnebago, the company best known for RVs, sees a bright future in pontoon boats.

The company is buying Barletta Pontoon Boats for as much as $320 million. The deal comes after interest in boating and other outdoorsy pursuits exploded during the pandemic. Sales of new pontoon boats jumped about 17% in 2020 from the year earlier.

"The vessels are versatile, family-friendly and usually a less expensive option, making them particularly popular among new boating enthusiasts," writes Brooke Sutherland.

It remains to be seen if Americans’ zeal for boats will have staying power. Tap the link in our bio to read Sutherland's column in full.

#barlettapontoonboats #pontoonboat #pontoon #boat #lakelife #rv #winnebago

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion in Måløv. May be an image of 1 person, standing, indoor and text that says 'This weig weight-los drug could help millions of obese Americans BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
The prevalence of adult obesity in the U.S. jumped from 30.5% to 42.4% between 1999 and 2018, a concerning rise in a significant driver of ailments like diabetes, heart disease and cancer.

"A drug that can help obese people safely cut an average of 15% of their body weight sounds like a miracle for those who can’t keep pounds off with diet and exercise alone," writes Max Nisen.

Wegovy, a Novo Nordisk drug that the U.S. Food and Drug Administration recently approved, appears to do exactly that.

Despite that exciting data, it’s not clear that many of those who could use the drug will end up taking it because of uncertain insurance coverage. The drug, which is a weekly injection, costs $1,350 a month.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the drug.

#obesity #america #weight #weightloss #treatment #pharma #wegovy #fda

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion in New Jersey. May be an image of text that says 'New Jersey New Jersey' debtis most desired by investors Texas U.S. California New York Massachusetts 30% 20 2018 2019 2020 Barclays Municipal Bond Indexes -10 2021 BloombergOpinion Opinion'.

node.text:
Let's hear it for New Jersey! New Jersey is one of only seven states with an improving economy over the last 3.5 years, measured by employment, personal income, home prices, tax receipts, mortgage delinquencies and the equity of their companies. It’s the only one of those seven with perennial leadership in public education and health care.

Investors have made New Jersey the most lucrative holding among the five largest municipal borrowers with a total return of 21.7% since the beginning of 2018. That means it's crushing California, New York, Texas, and Massachusetts.

Tap the link in our bio to find out what makes New Jersey so great. #newjersey #unitedstates #economy

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion in Sydney, Australia. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'How Australia's Covid-19 strategy went wrong OPERA Bloomb'.

node.text:
🇦🇺 From May last year until a few weeks ago, life in Sydney, Australia had been close to normal, beyond the usual routine of QR codes and closed borders. Even face masks had largely disappeared.

“Less than five dozen cases of local transmission occurred in my home state of New South Wales this year until June 16, when a limousine driver carrying flight crew from the airport caught the delta variant,” writes David Fickling.

The outbreak that resulted has now infected more than 700 people, and brought Sydney to a standstill.

While many parts of the world are emerging from a year of restrictions into glorious summer, Sydney is entering its winter of discontent.

What could have gone so wrong? The lessons are familiar ones for Australia. Tap the link in our bio to find out.

#australia #sydney #covid #deltavariant #delta #coronavirus

node.text:
Sometime next month, for the first time, the U.S. government is likely to declare a water shortage at Lake Mead. Arizona and its farmers will get hit first, but the water crisis will touch everyone.

🔗Tap the link in our bio read Tim O'Brien's deep dive inside the Southwest’s two-decade mega-drought.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Should you put Bitcoin into your individual retirement account? 30m Indicators BTC/USD 35844-295(-0.82%) 35844 30 Bitfinex 42000 41000 40000 39000 38000 37000 35844 35000 BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Salespeople have been blanketing potential investors with email pitches urging them to put Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies into individual retirement accounts. They tout eye-popping gains, warn of scary inflation and highlight endorsements to help legitimize the asset.

"For those relatively new to the world of crypto, including experienced market investors, buying into the hype using money earmarked for retirement could prove disastrous," writes Alexis Leondis.

While companies like Bitcoin IRA may provide some protective guardrails, there's still so much that could go wrong. Tap the link in our bio to learn more.

#retirement #bitcoin #btc #crypto #ira

node.text:
Almost all of the remaining restrictions imposed to fight the Covid-19 pandemic in England have now been lifted.

Even as the delta variant drives a rebound in infections, the government is determined to get customers back into shops, diners back into bars and restaurants, people out and about. Mark Gilbert is going to skip the celebration.

"We seem to be repeating some of the worst mistakes made at the start of the pandemic, but without the excuse of ignorance about the risks posed by the virus to absolve our collective foolishness," explains Gilbert.

Tap the link in our bio to read more. #freedomday #england #borisjohnson

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on July 18, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
A miracle drug to treat Covid-19 would sure be great, but do they actually work?

The hope that vaccines would send the virus into retreat with herd immunity is fading as the more transmissible delta variant sweeps across the globe, cases rise, and the vaccine-hesitant millions dig in.

Now that clinical studies have dampened enthusiasm for hydroxychloroquine, touted early in the pandemic by President Donald Trump, some scientists are pointing to promising studies of an anti-parasitic medicine called Ivermectin.

But there’s a problem. Experts disagree on the conclusions to be drawn from clinical studies of Ivermectin, and the laboratory experiments that propelled the drug into trials in the first place suggest that it only fights the virus effectively at doses likely to be toxic.

"As with hydroxychloroquine, high hopes for Ivermectin owe more to politics than to science," writes Faye Flam.

Tap the link in our bio to read all about whether we should hold out hope for an effective Covid miracle cure.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on July 18, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The number of hungry people around the world is growing again East Asia Southeast Asia Rest of the world Middle East North Africa India Sub-Saharan Africa 800M 600 400 200 2000 2005 Source: Soue:Foodand Agriculture Organization 2010 2015 2019 BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
The cost of food imports, which feed four-fifths of the world, is expected to rise to $1.7 trillion this year.

Break that down, and you find the bill for emerging economies jumping by more than a fifth, compared to a 6% increase for wealthier countries.

This creates the risk of unrest. At least 155 million people faced acute hunger last year — 20 million more than in 2019.

"People do not just riot about food, and in fact the starving rarely do so at all. But they do rise up against injustice that hampers their right to affordable nutrition — and the sort of inequities laid bare during the pandemic," writes Clara Ferreira Marques.

Yet the silent problems piling up for the longer term should worry us more. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the true cost of rising food prices around the globe.
